Study and Communication Skills Tutorials

HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This 15-credit first-year skills module is mainly concerned with building students’ study skills and building a solid foundation for employability development. It will focus on developing student’s communication and writing skills via a series of fortnightly tutorials. and frequent lectures. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered. We will work closely with the Careers and Employability team. This module will be built around fortnightly small group tutorials with Academic Advisors. Students will complete tasks that count towards a Portfolio and three larger assessments.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:
● provide the tools to develop communication skills required for higher education’;

● develop students’ ability to reflect on their progress and use feedback to identify opportunities for personal development;

● develop students’ appreciation of the application of these skills to future employment;

● teach students to work effectively in small groups;

● help students develop a professional relationship with peers and academics;
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will develop students’ transferable skills. It will focus on improving the students’ written, communication, and employability skills via a series of fortnightly tutorials and lectures. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered. Students will complete tasks that count towards a Portfolio and three larger assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Lecture and tutorial themes:

The syllabus will focus on the development of a number of skills that will support students’ learning throughout their BSc or MBiol programme, and will contribute to their employability thereafter. It will consolidate and build on students’ previous experience before university, which will inevitably be very diverse.

Throughout the module, students will reflect on their skills development, beginning with a skills audit and involving explicit reflection on feedback from assessments.

Writing and digital skills are a focus of this module, with the three primary summative assessments being substantial pieces of written work (an essay and written science communication) and a presentation. The drafting and submission of these assessments will be supported by skills development in the following areas:

• Essay writing skills
• Academic integrity
• Library skills
• Literature/internet search
• Referencing

The following additional skills and opportunities will be introduced and developed:

• Designing and delivering presentations
• Introduction to career development
• Placement/study abroad opportunities
• Job applications/CV writing

These underpinning and additional skills will be recorded and assessed within the reflective portfolio. Submission of summative assessments will be through Canvas. Students will be expected to maintain their portfolio, prepare for small group tutorials and to carry out independent research to develop the content of their summative assessments.

In addition to lectures on skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures relating to Science and Civic Society. These lectures may include topics such as the history and philosophy of science, decolonising sciences, sustainable development goals and equality, diversity and inclusivity. The lectures will form the basis for discussions in small group tutorials.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability. Students will also receive lectures relating to Science and Society Civic Service Award and programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials. Tutorial topics will include e.g. research skills, writing skills, and career development. In the tutorial, anonymous examples of ideal and not ideal resources will be evaluated and discussed.

The portfolio will contain a number of small tasks which include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as the presentation and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills. The assessment tasks will be marked using simple rubrics. In addition to the portfolio there are three marked written assessments, one in Semester 1 and two in Semester 2. Tutorial tasks will prepare and develop students’ writing skills and students will be required to submit a formative draft for the essay and written science communication.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Individual and group feedback on authentic-assessments and self-reflections aim to support the development of study and employability skills, such as resilience and ability to recognise, and act upon, constructive feedback.

Assessment 1. Portfolio
A key component of the assessment is therefore the production of a skills/self-reflection portfolio.

Assessment 2. Essay
Essay will be programme specific and be based contemporary issue

Assessment 3. Scientific Report
Based on a laboratory experiment

Assessment 4. Lay summary.
Programme specific topic

Three written assignments are designed to be authentic and will require students to combine all the skills they have developed over the course of the module. Furthermore, the assessments will help 1st year students to start to appreciate that learning in HE is about developing the ability to utilise a range of skills and expertise e.g. literature searching, communication, and creativity to address real-life situations.


Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Module Code:BIOS105
Deliveries:Liverpool campus · Whole Session

Details
Module Title
Study and Communication Skills Tutorials
Short Title
Study and Communication Skills
Module Code
BIOS105
Academic Year
2024-25
Org Unit
Life Sciences NEW

Liverpool campus

27 Sep 2023, 12:30
External Examiner(s)
Julia Cooke
Continuing Professional Development
No
Maximum Places
450
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This 15-credit first-year skills module is mainly concerned with building students’ study skills and building a solid foundation for employability development. It will focus on developing student’s communication and writing skills via a series of fortnightly tutorials. and frequent lectures. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered. We will work closely with the Careers and Employability team. This module will be built around fortnightly small group tutorials with Academic Advisors. Students will complete tasks that count towards a Portfolio and three larger assessments.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:
● provide the tools to develop communication skills required for higher education’;

● develop students’ ability to reflect on their progress and use feedback to identify opportunities for personal development;

● develop students’ appreciation of the application of these skills to future employment;

● teach students to work effectively in small groups;

● help students develop a professional relationship with peers and academics;
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will develop students’ transferable skills. It will focus on improving the students’ written, communication, and employability skills via a series of fortnightly tutorials and lectures. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered. Students will complete tasks that count towards a Portfolio and three larger assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Lecture and tutorial themes:

The syllabus will focus on the development of a number of skills that will support students’ learning throughout their BSc or MBiol programme, and will contribute to their employability thereafter. It will consolidate and build on students’ previous experience before university, which will inevitably be very diverse.

Throughout the module, students will reflect on their skills development, beginning with a skills audit and involving explicit reflection on feedback from assessments.

Writing and digital skills are a focus of this module, with the three primary summative assessments being substantial pieces of written work (an essay and written science communication) and a presentation. The drafting and submission of these assessments will be supported by skills development in the following areas:

• Essay writing skills
• Academic integrity
• Library skills
• Literature/internet search
• Referencing

The following additional skills and opportunities will be introduced and developed:

• Designing and delivering presentations
• Introduction to career development
• Placement/study abroad opportunities
• Job applications/CV writing

These underpinning and additional skills will be recorded and assessed within the reflective portfolio. Submission of summative assessments will be through Canvas. Students will be expected to maintain their portfolio, prepare for small group tutorials and to carry out independent research to develop the content of their summative assessments.

In addition to lectures on skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures relating to Science and Civic Society. These lectures may include topics such as the history and philosophy of science, decolonising sciences, sustainable development goals and equality, diversity and inclusivity. The lectures will form the basis for discussions in small group tutorials.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability. Students will also receive lectures relating to Science and Society Civic Service Award and programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials. Tutorial topics will include e.g. research skills, writing skills, and career development. In the tutorial, anonymous examples of ideal and not ideal resources will be evaluated and discussed.

The portfolio will contain a number of small tasks which include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as the presentation and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills. The assessment tasks will be marked using simple rubrics. In addition to the portfolio there are three marked written assessments, one in Semester 1 and two in Semester 2. Tutorial tasks will prepare and develop students’ writing skills and students will be required to submit a formative draft for the essay and written science communication.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Individual and group feedback on authentic-assessments and self-reflections aim to support the development of study and employability skills, such as resilience and ability to recognise, and act upon, constructive feedback.

Assessment 1. Portfolio
A key component of the assessment is therefore the production of a skills/self-reflection portfolio.

Assessment 2. Essay
Essay will be programme specific and be based contemporary issue

Assessment 3. Scientific Report
Based on a laboratory experiment

Assessment 4. Lay summary.
Programme specific topic

Three written assignments are designed to be authentic and will require students to combine all the skills they have developed over the course of the module. Furthermore, the assessments will help 1st year students to start to appreciate that learning in HE is about developing the ability to utilise a range of skills and expertise e.g. literature searching, communication, and creativity to address real-life situations.


Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin

Blurb
Overview
This 15-credit first-year skills module is mainly concerned with building students’ study skills and building a solid foundation for employability development. It will focus on developing student’s communication and writing skills via a series of fortnightly tutorials. and frequent lectures. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered. We will work closely with the Careers and Employability team. This module will be built around fortnightly small group tutorials with Academic Advisors. Students will complete tasks that count towards a Portfolio and three larger assessments.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:
● provide the tools to develop communication skills required for higher education’;

● develop students’ ability to reflect on their progress and use feedback to identify opportunities for personal development;

● develop students’ appreciation of the application of these skills to future employment;

● teach students to work effectively in small groups;

● help students develop a professional relationship with peers and academics;
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module will develop students’ transferable skills. It will focus on improving the students’ written, communication, and employability skills via a series of fortnightly tutorials and lectures. As this module is taken by students on all programmes, to allow students to explore their interests different essay titles, journal papers and discussion topics relevant to students programme area of interest will be offered. Students will complete tasks that count towards a Portfolio and three larger assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Lecture and tutorial themes:

The syllabus will focus on the development of a number of skills that will support students’ learning throughout their BSc or MBiol programme, and will contribute to their employability thereafter. It will consolidate and build on students’ previous experience before university, which will inevitably be very diverse.

Throughout the module, students will reflect on their skills development, beginning with a skills audit and involving explicit reflection on feedback from assessments.

Writing and digital skills are a focus of this module, with the three primary summative assessments being substantial pieces of written work (an essay and written science communication) and a presentation. The drafting and submission of these assessments will be supported by skills development in the following areas:

• Essay writing skills
• Academic integrity
• Library skills
• Literature/internet search
• Referencing

The following additional skills and opportunities will be introduced and developed:

• Designing and delivering presentations
• Introduction to career development
• Placement/study abroad opportunities
• Job applications/CV writing

These underpinning and additional skills will be recorded and assessed within the reflective portfolio. Submission of summative assessments will be through Canvas. Students will be expected to maintain their portfolio, prepare for small group tutorials and to carry out independent research to develop the content of their summative assessments.

In addition to lectures on skills development and employability, students will also receive lectures relating to Science and Civic Society. These lectures may include topics such as the history and philosophy of science, decolonising sciences, sustainable development goals and equality, diversity and inclusivity. The lectures will form the basis for discussions in small group tutorials.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete either before or after the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. In addition to the plenary lectures relating to skills development and employability. Students will also receive lectures relating to Science and Society Civic Service Award and programme specific content. These lectures will form the basis for discussions in programme specific tutorials. Tutorial topics will include e.g. research skills, writing skills, and career development. In the tutorial, anonymous examples of ideal and not ideal resources will be evaluated and discussed.

The portfolio will contain a number of small tasks which include a skills audit, reflection on module tasks such as the presentation and opportunity to reflect on academic feedback and the development of skills. The assessment tasks will be marked using simple rubrics. In addition to the portfolio there are three marked written assessments, one in Semester 1 and two in Semester 2. Tutorial tasks will prepare and develop students’ writing skills and students will be required to submit a formative draft for the essay and written science communication.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment. Individual and group feedback on authentic-assessments and self-reflections aim to support the development of study and employability skills, such as resilience and ability to recognise, and act upon, constructive feedback.

Assessment 1. Portfolio
A key component of the assessment is therefore the production of a skills/self-reflection portfolio.

Assessment 2. Essay
Essay will be programme specific and be based contemporary issue

Assessment 3. Scientific Report
Based on a laboratory experiment

Assessment 4. Lay summary.
Programme specific topic

Three written assignments are designed to be authentic and will require students to combine all the skills they have developed over the course of the module. Furthermore, the assessments will help 1st year students to start to appreciate that learning in HE is about developing the ability to utilise a range of skills and expertise e.g. literature searching, communication, and creativity to address real-life situations.


Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
